'''Ethnic Ukrainian music''' includes many varieties of [[folk music|folk]], [[popular music|popular]] and [[European classical music|classical]] traditions. Ethnic music is especially associated with classical styles of [[ballet (music)|ballet]] and [[opera]], of which composers like [[Mykola Lysenko]], [[Lev Revutsky]], [[Mykola Dremliuha]], [[Yevhen Stankovych]], [[Myroslav Skoryk]] are among the most well-known.  Late in the [[19th century]], elements of Ukrainian folk music began to be used in [[orchestra]]l works. 
In the 20th century ethnographic ensembles were established and gained popularity.

In the [[20th century]], operatic singers like [[Modest Mencinsky]] and [[Solomea Krushelnycki]] were popular. During the [[Soviet]] era, national music in the [[USSR]] was tightly controlled. The repertoire of Ukrainian ethnographic ensembles was restricted.

Among the most popular singers of Ukrainian folk music in the modern era are [[Nina Matvienko]],  

In the 1970's Ukrainian folk songs and elements began to be included in pop and rock music in the rock-oriented [[Kobza ensemble]], [[Smerichka]],

==Traditional instruments==
===String===
*[[Bandura]] - a multi stringed lute-zither played with the fingers.  
*[[Kobza]] - four-stringed [[lute]] with a rounded soundboard, plucked or strummed with a [[plectum]].
*[[Lira]] - a Ukrainian [[hurdy-gurdy]] with an oval or cello shaped body and an attached triangular keybox.
*[[Gudok|Hudok]] - a three-stringed, pear-shaped Ukrainian bowed instrument which is usually held vertically.
*[[Gusli|Husli]] - one of the oldest known Ukrainian musical instruments, described by the Greeks as early as the 6th century CE.  Many different versions of this plucked string instrument exist.
*[[Torban]] - a relative of the bandura with its  own unique tuning.
*[[Tsymbaly]] - a relative of the [[cymbalom]] with its  own unique tuning.
*[[Skrypka]] - a relative of the [[violin]].
*[[Basolia]] - a relative of the [[cello]] with its own unique tuning and method of tuning.

===Wind===
*[[Sopilka]] - simple fipple flute in various sizes
*[[Zholomiha]] - a double fipple flute
*[[Floyara]] - a non fipple flute 
*[[Frilka]] - a smaller verion of the floyara
*[[Dentsivka]] - a hollow pipe with no additional air holes, used for whistling sounds.
*[[Sviril]] - Ukrainian [[panpipe]].
*[[Truba]] - a wooden [[trumpet]].
*[[Surma]] - a folk oboe or [[shawm]].
*[[Rih]] - Ukrainian folk [[clarinet]]/[[hornpipe (musical instrument)|hornpipe]].
*[[Trembita]] - Alpine horn
*[[Volynka]] - traditional [[Slavic peoples|Slavic]] [[bagpipe]].

===Percussion===
*[[Buben]]
*[[Bubentsy]]

*[[Lozhky]] - decorated wooden spoons.
*[[Rubel]]
*[[Trishchotky]] - set of wooden boards on a string that are clapped together as a group.
*[[Vertushka]]
*[[Zvonchalka]]

===Other recently introduced folk instruments===

The vinok varied in many of the regions of Ukraine, young women throughout the country wore various headdresses of yarn, ribbon, coins, feathers and grasses, but these all had the same symbolic meaning.  In parts of [[central]] and [[Eastern Ukraine|eastern]] [[Ukraine]] the flowers were raised in the center front.  Usually multicolored, embroidered ribbons are attached to the back.

The vinok is now worn by traditional [[Ukrainian dance|Ukrainian dancers]].

''Qırım'' is Crimean Tatar for "my hill" (''qır'' – hill, ''-ım'' – my). Russian ''Krym'' is a Russified form of Qırım. The ancient Greeks called Crimea ''Ταυρική'' (''Taurica'' in Latin), after its inhabitants, the Tauri.

The Soviet Union was a communist country with a totalitarian regime that existed from 1917 until 1991.  The official name was "The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics" (USSR).  The country stretched from the [[Baltic Sea|Baltic]] and [[Black Sea|Black Seas]] to the [[Pacific Ocean]].  In its final years it consisted of 15 [[Soviet Socialist Republics]] (SSR's).  [[Russia]] was by far the largest Republic in the Soviet Union in terms of both land area and population, and also dominated it politically and economically.

During the period of its existence, the Soviet Union was by area perhaps the largest [[country|countries]], or [[empire|empires]], the world had ever seen.  It was also one of the most diverse, with more than 100 distinct national ethnicities living within its borders.  The Soviet Union was so large, in fact, that even ''after'' many associated republics gained independence, the Soviet Union's successor, [[Russia]], remained easily the largest country by area (with [[Canada]] second), and remained quite ethnically diverse, including, e.g., minorities of [[Tatar|Tatars]], [[Udmurt|Udmurts]], and many other non-Russian ethnicities.

The first leader of the Soviet Union was [[Vladimir Lenin]], who led the [[Communists]] (then called [[Bolsheviks]]) to power in the [[Russian Revolution]] of [[1917]].  After Lenin died in [[1924]], power gradually consolidated in the hands of [[Joseph Stalin]], who led the Soviet Union until his death in [[1953]].
